title: Trump’s Foray Into Venezuela Could Embolden Russia’s and China’s Own Aggression
summary: While both countries were allied with Nicolás Maduro, the U.S. attack could give them justification to use force in other spheres, analysts said.

title: Venezuela Braces for Economic Collapse From U.S. Blockade
summary: Venezuela could lose the bulk of its export revenues this year if the U.S. blockade stays in place, according to internal government estimates, a scenario that would set off a humanitarian crisis.

title: Stephen Miller Asserts U.S. Has Right to Take Greenland
summary: In a CNN interview, the top Trump aide also echoed the president’s intent to run Venezuela as he laid out a case for the United States’ controlling weaker states by flexing its military might.

title: RFK Jr. Scales Back the Number of Vaccines Recommended for Children
summary: Federal health officials now recommend that children be routinely inoculated against 11 diseases, not 17, citing standards in other wealthy nations.

title: What to Know About the New Childhood Vaccine Schedule
summary: The U.S. federal government slashed the number of diseases that all children are advised to be vaccinated against to 11 from 17.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Prohibition on Trump’s Medical Research Cuts
summary: The ruling on Monday upheld a lower court’s judgment in April that the Trump administration could not drastically slash funding from the National Institutes of Health.

title: For Many Jan. 6 Rioters, a Pardon From Trump Wasn’t Enough
summary: Some pardoned rioters have been rearrested. Others returned to poverty and mental health challenges. And many became consumed by resentment and demands for payback.

title: Zelensky’s Assessment Darkens as Europeans Gather to Talk Peace
summary: With Russia still seen as unlikely to stop fighting, the Ukrainian leader’s tone has shifted from upbeat to cautionary.

title: Zelensky Taps High-Profile Canadian Politician as Economic Adviser
summary: Ukraine’s president appointed Chrystia Freeland, a former deputy prime minister of Canada, to a role in which she would advise on postwar reconstruction, if peace talks are successful.

title: Hegseth Starts Proceedings Against Sen. Mark Kelly Over His Remarks
summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth blasted the senator for “seditious” remarks. Mr. Kelly said he had done nothing wrong and cited similar comments by Mr. Hegseth.

title: Corporation for Public Broadcasting Votes to Shut Down
summary: Executives debated whether to allow the corporation to lie dormant after federal funding ended last year, but decided against it.

title: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz Abandons Re-election Bid, and Amy Klobuchar May Run Instead
summary: Mr. Walz said a growing scandal over fraud in social services programs led him to abandon his run for a third term as governor of Minnesota.

title: Trump’s Post About Slain Minnesota Lawmaker Dismays Her Children
summary: The son and daughter of Melissa and Mark Hortman have asked the president to remove a social media post promoting a conspiracy theory about the assassination.

title: Six Big Political Questions for 2026
summary: A wildly important midterm year is off to a chaotic start, with a raid in Venezuela, an uneasy economy and more. Here’s what we’re curious about.

title: Israel’s Stinging Retort to Mamdani Was Meant as Retaliation in Kind
summary: After Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York scrapped two executive orders on antisemitism and boycotts, the Israeli Foreign Ministry issued an aggressive response to what it saw as an aggressive act.

title: Zohran Mamdani Targets Junk Fees and Hidden Charges in Executive Orders
summary: Trying to protect consumers by going after deceptive business practices has been an early focus of the new mayor’s administration.

title: Mamdani Chooses a Bernie Sanders Aide as His Communications Director
summary: Anna Bahr, who leads communications for the Vermont senator and worked on his presidential campaign, is the latest appointee to a high-profile role in the Mamdani administration.

title: Nvidia Details New A.I. Chips and Autonomous Car Project With Mercedes
summary: At the CES conference, Jensen Huang, the company’s chief executive, said the more efficient and powerful chip would begin shipping later this year.

title: At Refugee Camps, Most Birthdays Fall on New Year’s
summary: When an exodus of Rohingya fled to Bangladesh a decade ago, the United Nations recorded many of their birthdays as Jan. 1. The date serves as a reminder of a lost identity.

title: Waymo Has Come for the Kids in Los Angeles
summary: Because families have complicated schedules.

title: Dance Moves From the Street, City Edition
summary: Dancers from Detroit, Chicago and Philadelphia demonstrate the fundamentals of their styles, revealing deep historical roots.

title: Donald Trump Was Right to Oust Maduro
summary: President Trump made a bold decision, and it was a stunning success.

title: Jamie Raskin: Jan. 6 Never Ended
summary: Five years after Jan. 6, 2021, we are still caught up in a struggle over the meaning of that day.

title: Maduro Pleads Not Guilty
summary: Also, health officials scaled back the number of vaccines recommended for children. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.

title: Hilton ‘Maliciously Canceled’ Immigration Agents’ Reservations, DHS Says
summary: As the U.S. ramps up deportation efforts in Minnesota, the Department of Homeland Security claimed on social media that a Hampton Inn had canceled agents’ bookings.

title: Eva Schloss, Anne Frank’s Stepsister and Holocaust Survivor, Dies at 96
summary: Freed from Auschwitz, she was silent about her ordeal for four decades. Then she decided to dedicate her life to educating people about the dangers of prejudice.

title: Steve Sheetz, Who Popularized Convenience Stores as a C.E.O., Dies at 77
summary: Sheetz, a family-owned company that started with a single convenience store in Altoona, Pa., has more than 800 locations in seven states.

title: Mamdani and Hochul Celebrate Congestion Pricing a Year After Contentious Debut
summary: The tolling program, which charges motorists to enter Manhattan’s busiest streets, had a largely successful first year after a delayed start.
